BEN: Fortitude, can you read us? We need help. Urgent help. Come in. Nothing. Still nothing.
GENEVIEVE: The storm’s getting worse.
DOCTOR: I won’t be beaten by bad weather!
GENEVIEVE: Doctor, the Professor’s not going to make it. Neither are we.
DOCTOR: No. Ben, switch that on again.
BEN: What? It’s just that interference.
DOCTOR: I want to hear it again.
GENEVIEVE: But you’ve heard it before. We’ve all heard it. There’s nothing else.
DOCTOR: Yes, I heard it before. I want to hear it again. Ben!
BEN: Okay, okay.
DOCTOR: That sound. Come on, come on. What are you telling me?
GELDAR: We owe you so much, Doctor.
DOCTOR: All in a day’s work.
GELDAR: You treat this matter with such lightness, my friend, but I know you understand.
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, I do, Geldar.
GELDAR: Even now it feels as if this isn’t over. The thought of Arakssor’s vision for our people’s future still haunts me.
DOCTOR: And so it should. That way you'll never let it happen again.
DOCTOR: Oh no.
GELDAR: No, Doctor. Arakssor and his cohorts have broken out of their cells.
DOCTOR: How did this happen?
GELDAR: The guards. We have been betrayed. It is too late, Doctor. You must save yourself. They will show no mercy.
DOCTOR: Have you activated your distress signal?
GELDAR: The power has been cut..
DOCTOR: Go to the communications chamber and switch the signal on from there. I'll find a way to reconnect the power on my way back to the Tardis.
DOCTOR: That sound. A distress signal.
BEN: What’s he saying?
GENEVIEVE: Doctor. Doctor!
BEN: I don’t know if he can hear you. I think his mind’s gone. How’s the Professor?
GENEVIEVE: I couldn’t wake him. He just wanted to sleep. He wouldn't listen to me.
BEN: You ask me, he’s the lucky one.
GENEVIEVE: Ben, we are not going to...
BEN: Try not to think about it.
ARAKSSOR: You have done well, humans.
BARSET: What is this place?
ARAKSSOR: A communications chamber.
BARSET: Who's that?
ARAKSSOR: That is Geldar.
BARSET: Is he a friend of yours?
ARAKSSOR: Geldar is... at my mercy.
HARMAN: I think he’s waking up.
BARSET: I’ve a feeling he’s going to regret that.
HARMAN: What's that noise we’ve been hearing? We picked it up on our radio before.
ARAKSSOR: Ssrongar.
SSRONGAR: Yes, my Lord.
ARAKSSOR: Switch it off.
ARAKSSOR: What noise?
DOCTOR: That's it! The transmitter. Try it again, now.
BEN: Doctor, there’s no point, mate.
DOCTOR: All right, I'll do it myself. Right, now how does this thing work?
GENEVIEVE: Doctor, why are you doing this? You won’t get through. We haven’t moved since we last tried.
DOCTOR: Go ahead, Ben. They'll recognise your voice.
BEN: Doc, just give it up, will you?
DOCTOR: Ben!
BEN: This is Ben Hodgson calling Fortitude. Do you read me? Over.
GENEVIEVE: I suppose it was worth
FORTITUDE: [OC]: This is Fortitude. Fortitude receiving. Your signal is very weak. Can you hear us? Over.
DOCTOR: Is anyone going to answer that?
SSRONGAR: The transmission strength was weak. It was only activated by energy from the human’s heat emitters.
ARAKSSOR: Is there a record of any response?
SSRONGAR: No, Lord Arakssor.
ARAKSSOR: Good.
HARMAN: Do you know what the hell they’re talking about?
BARSET: I’m not sure, but let’s just keep quiet for now, eh, Harman, there’s a good chap.
GELDAR: Arakssor, what have you done?
ARAKSSOR: Ah, Geldar. Welcome back to the land of the living. You always assume I am to blame.
GELDAR: What is your meaning?
ARAKSSOR: That we owe our re-awakening to these humans.
GELDAR: Humans?
ARAKSSOR: The dominant race that emerged on the blue planet while we remained encased in ice for millions of years.
GELDAR: So our people have been free of your madness for millions of years. I am thankful.
ARAKSSOR: Thankful that the warriors of the red planet have lived the lives of cowards? You are a traitor to our race, Geldar.
GELDAR: If wanting peace and co-existence with the rest of the galaxy is treachery, then I plead guilty.
ARAKSSOR: Under my rule, we would have been masters of the galaxy, not cowering scum who consort with inferiors.
GELDAR: We were glad of the alien Doctor’s help in preventing your military coup. My only regret is that your sentence has been interrupted.
ARAKSSOR: The sentence was unlawful. I did not recognise the authority of your court, and neither did my followers, and there were many. My ideals will have lived on. I will reclaim my empire, return to the red planet, but first I will make a fortress of this world.
GELDAR: I would wish my people dead rather than think of them under your rule.
ARAKSSOR: Then perhaps I can save you from those terrible thoughts, Geldar. You have already pleaded guilty. The sentence is death.
BARSET: Don’t, Harman. Keep back.
ARAKSSOR: Ssrongar, have you located the sonic cannon?
SSRONGAR: Yes, Lord.
ARAKSSOR: Excellent. We will use it to alter this planet’s atmospheric gases to make it habitable for our
ARAKSSOR: armies. I will begin the calculations.
SSRONGAR: What of these humans?
ARAKSSOR: Lord Barset.
BARSET: Yes?
ARAKSSOR: What would you do in my position?
BARSET: You mean if I'd been asleep for millions of years? Well, I don’t know. I’d probably
ARAKSSOR: You know what I mean. You have heard my words. You know I plan to obliterate all life on this planet.
BARSET: Well, no, actually, I hadn’t gathered that. You said something about altering atmospheric gases. I didn’t automatically assume
ARAKSSOR: You say much that has no meaning, Lord Barset. Could it be that you talk merely to prolong your own existence?
HARMAN: You said you owed us yout lives.
BARSET: Harman, for goodness’ sake.
ARAKSSOR: Let your warrior Captain speak.
HARMAN: You said that to your... your dead friend there. And you were right, weren't you. I mean, if it wasn’t for us, you'd still be frozen.
ARAKSSOR: That is true.
HARMAN: Well, you’re warriors, right?
ARAKSSOR: Yes.
HARMAN: Don't you have some kind of warrior’s code or, or, or something?
ARAKSSOR: Do you fear me, warrior Captain?
BARSET: Oh, yes, certainly. We both fear you. Absolutely.
ARAKSSOR: And you both know that if you try to escape you will be killed instantly.
BARSET: Yes.
HARMAN: Yes.
ARAKSSOR: They may be of use to us. They may live, for now.
PILOT: [OC]: This is Blade One. We have a visual on your party, Ben. Over.
BEN: Blade One, we see you. Can you land?
PILOT: [OC]: That’s a negative, Ben. Weather’s too bad for us. We'll come in as low as we can and drop a ladder for you. Over.
GENEVIEVE: The Professor. What about him?
PILOT: [OC]: You’re going to have to leave the Professor there for now. We're noting the map reference down. We'll return when the weather’s improved. Over.
DOCTOR: Jenny, there’s nothing we can do for him now.
GENEVIEVE: Yes. Oh yes, I know.
BEN: Understood, Blade One. Over.
PILOT: [OC]: Sending the ladder down now, Ben. Out.
BARSET: And that must be the sonic cannon we’ve been hearing so much about.
HARMAN: You know there isn’t a guard out there.
BARSET: What? Maybe Arakssor expects us to keep our word. That warrior’s code you were blathering on about. Well done though, Harman. Quick thinking.
HARMAN: Yeah, thanks. But what the hell are they going to use us for, eh? Something not good, and that’s for sure.
BARSET: Hey, wait a minute. They really have all gone. Probably taking that thing up to the surface.
HARMAN: Oh no, you’re not actually thinking of making a run for it?
BARSET: I’m not living by any make-believe warrior’s code., Harman. You’re right. Whatever Arakssor wants us for isn’t going to be good for us, so let’s go, shall we?
HARMAN: But how? I mean, what are we going to do?
BARSET: Look, they’ve shut down that signal thing, haven’t they? I’ve got a hunch that means we'll be able to get through to Fortitude. Once we get a call through, we can get some help. Come on.
PILOT: This is Blade One to Fortitude. Now on final descent. Have on board Doctor Genevieve Marceau, Crewman Ben Hodgson.
DOCTOR: And the Doctor. Hello.
PILOT: No, I don’t know who he is either.
BEN: Look, Doc, I just want to know how you knew we’d get through on the radio that last time.
DOCTOR: Yes, so do I.
GENEVIEVE: What do you mean, so do you?
DOCTOR: Are you warm enough now?
GENEVIEVE: Look, I thought your memory was working again.
DOCTOR: Working again? Yes, it’s warming up like an old TV set. Ah, of course!
GENEVIEVE: What's the matter?
DOCTOR: Now we're really in trouble. Excuse me.
BEN: Doctor! He’s gone back to the helicopter. What’s the matter with that guy?
GENEVIEVE: Doctor!
PILOT: Understood. We just need to take a look at the fuel level, see what
DOCTOR: Excuse me, please.
PILOT: Ow! (distant) Hey! What are you doing? Get down
DOCTOR: Sorry, I’m in a hurry. (door closes) Right, now how does this thing fly? I’m sure I must have flown one before.
GENEVIEVE: Hey, where are we going?
DOCTOR: You should be in the sick bay.
GENEVIEVE: Doctor, are you crazy or something?
DOCTOR: No, you are, coming with me, Jenny. Hold onto something.
BARSET: Is it clear that way?
HARMAN: Yeah. No sign of them.
BARSET: What's the matter?
HARMAN: I was just thinking about Ben and the others, stuck out there.
BARSET: What about them?
HARMAN: Well, when we make the call, we should get Fortitude to send someone to look for them.
BARSET: First things first, Captain. The Professor’s lot haven’t got a bunch of homicidal aliens breathing down their necks, have they? Come on. Look out. Quick.
HARMAN: We'll have to go the other way.
BARSET: Oh no, there’s another one. Harman, look out! Argh!
GENEVIEVE: We shouldn't be flying in these conditions.
DOCTOR: You didn’t have to come along.
GENEVIEVE: No, but I thought you might need some help. Help to do what, by the way?
DOCTOR: Finish something I started millions of years ago.
GENEVIEVE: You’ve remembered something, haven’t you? Something to do with that signal.
DOCTOR: Yes. It was a distress call warning of Arakssor’s escape. It suddenly struck me that it would be his first priority to shut the signal down. By the way, do you always live so dangerously?
GENEVIEVE: Always.
DOCTOR: That’s just as well.
SSRONGAR: They were trying to escape
ARAKSSOR: [OC]: Did you destroy them?
SSRONGAR: Yes.
ARAKSSOR: Is the sonic cannon now in position?
SSRONGAR: [OC]: Yes, but its power reserve is almost depleted.
ARAKSSOR: The prison’s reactor is now attaining full function. We will connect the sonic cannon to it.
SSRONGAR: [OC]: What is that, Lord?
ARAKSSOR: I am detecting the approach of a flying craft. It seems the humans lied to us. Their Fortitude is able to reach us.
SSRONGAR: [OC]: I see it. It is a small craft, puny design.
ARAKSSOR: Activate the cannon’s power reserve and destroy it.
SSRONGAR: [OC]: Yes, Lord.
GENEVIEVE: Okay, I get it. You want to get these Ice Warrior things locked up again. But exactly how are you going to do that?
DOCTOR: You mean how are we going to do that?
GENEVIEVE: Yes. Just the two of us against the ah!
GENEVIEVE: What is that?
DOCTOR: Oh no! They’ve got a sonic cannon!
GENEVIEVE: Doctor, the helicopter’s falling apart.
DOCTOR: Hold on!

elements.text: [Part Four]
[OC]: Hello? Hello? This is...
Genevieve! What's the Doctor up to? Are you in trouble? Look, turn back, the weather’s too bad. Over.
[OC]: Ben, something’s... (unintelligible)... breaking up...
Breaking up? Did she just say...
[OC]: We're going (static)
Oh, my God.
Sonic cannon powers down.
Sonic cannon power now exhausted.
[OC]: Was the flying car destroyed?
Yes, Lord.
Good. You will now connect the sonic cannon to the prison’s reactor. I will begin calculations to modify the sonic beam for our purposes.
[OC]: Yes, Lord Arakssor.
Soon we will make this planet ours.
Who's in there? Is there anyone alive? Hello?
Yes, we’re alive.
You!
But you don’t look too well yourself, Lord Barset.
How did you survive?
Fell out with your Martian friends, did you? Give me a hand.
Steady. What... what happened?
We were shot down by a sonic cannon.
So, they used that thing on you, did they?
And on you?
I caught a blast of something a bit smaller, but it hurts. It hurts like hell.
It would. Sonic vibrations targeted at human cells, not pleasant at all.
Where’s Harman?
They killed him. Obviously thought they’d got me too.
They’re utterly ruthless. Hopefully, they think we’re all dead.
Why?
Because that way, they won’t be expecting us to sneak back to your base. Sorry the landing was so bumpy, Jenny. I was trying to make it look worse than it was.
Listen, Doctor, we’re alive. That’s good enough for me.
Look, why... why the hell do you want to go back there? I nearly got killed getting out.
Did you find out what the Martians are planning to do?
That’s why we made a run for it. They’re going to do something... something to the atmosphere.
Really. Hmm.
Something about turning the planet into their fortress.
And you really need to ask me why we have to go back? Come on.
Power cable is connected. Take the other end of the cable down to the control centre. I will await Lord Arakssor’s instructions.
Understood, Ssrongar.
Get back.
Well, presumably he didn’t see us.
No wonder that sonic blast wasn’t enough to destroy us.
It was bad enough.
Cannon’s power must be exhausted.
And that Martian was carrying a cable. Maybe they need to plug it into something.
Which means we still have some time.
How are we going to get past Ssrongar over there?
At least he’s looking the other way. But Ice Warriors have very good hearing, so the answer to your question is, very carefully. Follow my footsteps.

Red Control, respond. This is Arakssor. Respond! (static) Planetary scan. No signal. No life. The red planet is dead. Then the time of exodus has passed. No matter, there will be new armies to command, a new campaign, an empire to build, and then I will be avenged!
I found these in the sick bay. They’re pretty strong painkillers.
Will they work?
They'll have to do.
Look, I’m really in a lot of pain here so I’d appreciate it if you... I dunno, if you showed some compassion. You are supposed to be a doctor, after all.
Doctor, yes. That’s what people have been calling me for centuries.
Centuries? How much have you remembered?
That blue box is my ship.
The Police Box?
Yes, and we need to get to it.
Why? And how can it be your ship, anyway? It’s just, you know, made of wood.
Look, now that jamming signal has been switched off, we can just call up the Fortitude and get help.
What exactly do you know about that signal?
What? Not much. Just that Arakssor was quite keen to shut it off.
It was a distress signal, wasn’t it, Doctor?
Yes.
You mean a distress signal sent by that, that Geldar chap?
You’ve seen Geldar?
Arakssor had him thawed out then murdered him in cold blood.
Geldar. Anything else you haven’t been telling us?
Who put you in charge?
You did.
What?
The moment you abused your power and privilege to come on this foolhardy expedition.
I didn’t ask for the power and privilege, Doctor. And I thought I was going to do some good.
Ha. You just wanted to get your hands on the technology you thought was buried out here.
For the benefit of mankind.
Then why did you keep your grandfather’s diary a secret? Why didn’t you tell the world? Because you wanted it for yourself.
Yes. Yes, but only to prevent a free-for-all.
What do you mean?

I wanted any new technologies to unite the world, not to be sold off into a million competing franchises. All the potential benefit for ordinary real people would have been lost in branding and marketing. People would have ended up worrying about colour or design rather than how their lives could be changed for the better. I wanted to serve humanity’s future without grubby little brand executives and their petty empires getting in the way.
You wanted control and power however you dress the idea up, Lord Barset. You remind me a little of Arakssor.
I am not a murderer.
No, but people have died because you brought them here.
The Professor’s dead.
What? But I assumed you got picked up.
Too late for Mac.
Oh, I’m
Sorry? It doesn’t help.
All right, all right. But what does?
Information. You said the Ice Warriors wanted to do something to the atmosphere.
Yes.
And I think I know how.
Humming rising in pitch.
Ssrongar to control.
[OC]: Report, Ssrongar.
Sonic cannon power now at maximum.
[OC]: Excellent.
I have completed my calculations. Set the cannon to receive new energy settings.
[OC]: Settings received.
Elevate to maximum.
But how can sonic vibrations from that cannon change the molecular structure of the Earth’s greenhouse gases?
Oh, Arakssor’s something of a genius, despite his brutish nature.
But greenhouse gases into what, refrigerant gases? Is that what you’re saying?
Yes. He’s going to evaporate the heat out of the Earth’s atmosphere, and that means er, well, you know... let me think. If you calculate
Think?
Look, we’ve got to stop him, call for help.
Minus thirty two degrees Celsius.
What?
That’s how cold it’s going to get?
Eventually. The human race will be frozen out of existence. We need to get back to the Tardis. Ah.
The what?
So that’s what it’s called. Yes, right, oh, come on, quick. Pick up those batteries. We need to be quick to use our big advantage.
What’s that, you?
Oh, how nice of you to say so, Jenny, but I wasn’t actually thinking of that.
Then what were you thinking?
The Ice Warriors think we’re dead. Come on, let’s make mischief.
Good, good. The planet’s gases are changing. Colder, yes, colder. Now boosting power direct from the reactor to the cannon.
They are firing the cannon.
Yes, and it’s starting to have an effect on the atmosphere.
Big rumble.
Ah, what was that?
It’s ice. Chunks of ice. Are they causing an avalanche with that thing?
Giant frozen hail. Come on, before we get hit. This way. It’s over here.
Lord Barset, quickly.
Barset cries out.
Doctor, help me with him.
It knocked him straight out.
Lord Barset. Lord Barset!
Is he dead?
No. Come on, we’re going to have to carry him. We'll put him in one of the small chambers and come back for him later.
Ah, I thought so
What?

The Ice Warriors have ripped out the heat emitter power lines. Not big fans of heat. Right, home is where the hearth is. Now, if I can take this emitter into the Tardis, we can... oh no. My key. Where’s my key? I must have put it in my pocket. In my pocket! Where’s my pocket? These are not my clothes.
Wait a minute. Is this what you wanted?
Where did you get that?
Well, it was just sticking out of that thing when we found it. To be honest, I just put it in my pocket and forgot all about it. Are you sure this is all you need to open a spaceship? A key?
Why not give it a try?
Door unlocked, opened and closed.
Now, I’ve got work to do.
Er, Doctor?
Hmm? Yes?
It’s just... we did get inside that Police Box, didn’t we? That small Police Box?
Oh, yes, yes.
Yes, I thought so. Yes, okay.
Report, Ssrongar.
[OC]: My sentries report they have found the wreckage of the flying craft. There are no bodies.
And there has been a report of movement in the main chamber.
[OC]: I will investigate immediately.
Hmm.
What’s all that technology actually doing?
It’s scanning for any spaceship within transmission range, which gives me time to attach the heat emitter to this battery. Pass me that wire, would you?
So I’m guessing you’ve remembered quite a lot.
Oh yes, quite a lot, yes. It was that noise.
Recognition code, unlocking the secrets of your mind.
Genevieve Marceau. (kiss, kiss, kiss)
Yes, okay, you can remember my whole name now. I’m very impressed.

No, you’re a genius. The wave form of the distress signal will have certain characteristics in it. You know, bits of sound common to all Martian technology. That’s the key to finding an Ice Warrior’s spaceship. Here, hold this emitter.
What are you doing?
The sound of the signal is in my mind. I’m connecting to the telepathic circuits of the Tardis.
Your ship is telepathic?
Telepathic, and travels in Time and Space. And there’s a very nice swimming pool. Sometimes.
18’ OFFICER [OC]: Ben, any luck with getting through to the Naval Patrol?
Nothing, sir. The storm seems to be messing everything up. What are we going to do?
18’ OFFICER [OC]: We just have to sit tight. Weather’s too bad to take the Fortitude out to sea.

I know. Have you ever seen anything like it? Those hailstones are like footballs. Have you seen those clouds? Looks like the end of the bleeding world. I hope you’re all right out there, Mademoiselle.
Look, there on the scanner. You see?
That looks like the Milky Way.
It is. But there, look. That little blinking light.
An Ice Warrior spaceship?
An Ice Warrior spaceship, and it’s within reasonable range.
Reasonable? But that looks like it’s on the other side of the galaxy.
Oh, not all that far really. I mean, they have hyperdrive, you know. Now, I'll just have to make a note of those coordinates. Right. Must remember those.
Perhaps you ought to write them down.
Nonsense. I have an excellent memory. Well, now I have. I think.
So what now?
I reactivate and boost the distress signal. But in order to do that I'll have to use reactor power, and that’s what Arakssor is using to power his sonic cannon.
He’s not going to be very pleased if you have unplug his cannon, then.
Quite. Now, what’s outside? Just adjust the scanner. Oh dear.
An Ice Warrior.
Come on. Time to take the initiative. Hand me that heat emitter.
Tardis door opens.
Hello. Good afternoon.
Do not move.
What, not even to do this?
Anh! Sss. Aiiee. (Sonic weapon)
Doctor.
Not a very good shot when he’s having a hot flush, is he?
More noises then thud.
Is he dead?
Just a bit pooped out, I think. Right, now, get the other batteries from the Tardis and wire them up to all the other emitters here, then switch on. As quick as you can.
What are you going to be doing?
Putting my bare-faced cheek into a lion’s mouth.
Soon the effects will be irreversible. Their scientists will realise, and then it will be time to issue my ultimatum.
I’m sorry to pour hot water on your plans
Doctor.
But one of your warships is on its way here.
You lie.
I saw it in my craft. I'll show you if you don’t believe me.
I do not believe you. You worked with those traitors against me. Those who deposed and imprisoned me.
And now they’re homing in on the bearing of that signal. I can show you their position.
I could destroy them with the sonic cannon.
Presssssssiccccly.
Why would you help us?
To save the human race. You’re destroying their atmosphere.
The human race will survive as my slave army
But how many will perish before they submit? If you redirect your cannon now, the humans will be saved.
For the present. And you would risk your life to give them this brief respite? Such an action is pointless.
Is mercy pointless?
Yes.
Ah, there we differ.
I do not trust you, Doctor, or your craft. You will come with me to the communications chamber and show me this so-called ship.
Right, okay Jenny, that’s it I think. Ah, cross your fingers, Doctor. Let’s see if we can heat things up a little bit. It's working! Mon Dieu, it’s working.
Jenny, what the hell’s been going on? I woke up in some chamber or something.
Lord Barset.
Did you leave me for dead?
No, but we had things to do and
Where’s that mad Doctor? What’s he doing?
You’ll have to siphon off some of your reactor power.
Do not presume to lecture me. I know... I Know what... what I’m doing.
Ah, I was right, though, wasn’t I? So that lever controls the flow of energy from your reactor, does it? How do you reassign the power to different tasks? This panel?
Silence. Show me the coordinates of the warship.
Oh, temper, temper.
Look, you’ve caused enough trouble here, Barset. Just sit down and be quiet.
You've no right to speak to me like that. I paid you well, didn’t 1? Well, didn’t I?
That’s the trouble with you. You think money is everything.

No, no, no, no, that’s the trouble with the world. I’m just a victim of it, and that’s what I wanted to change. I wanted to free mankind from all that rubbish by giving them new technologies, new ways Of living.
Yes, maybe, but you wanted it to be you doing the giving, like some great benefactor, like the saviour of the human race.
I don’t have to listen to this. We’re wasting time. I’m a man of action and I’m going to put things right.
Where are you going?
The Ice Warriors have left plenty of my men’s guns around here, so...
What the hell do you think you’re doing?
I’m going to put my money where my mouth is and go straight to the top.
Oh no. Oh no!
And those are the coordinates?
Yes. I’m proud to say I remembered every digit. Oh now then, don’t get overheated.
The temperature. What have you done?
Getting a little hot for you, is it?
These coordinates. That warship is far too distant from this planet ever to have picked up that weak distress signal.
I know, which is why it needs a little boost!
No!
If you choke me, I'll never turn the heat down..
You cannot trick... trick me. You must not... must not... The heat... (thud)
Yes. Awful when the thermostat gets stuck, isn’t it? Now, where was I? Hmm.
Signal starts up and the Doctor hums along.
Ah yes, there you are. Good old faith.
Arakssor attacks.
Get off me!
I’m not finished yet, Doctor.
But... but you’re weakening.
Zut! That’s it, damn it. No more heat. Okay, okay. Right, here goes.
The Doctor cries out.
My strength is returning, Doctor. My warriors have foiled your pathetic plan, whatever it is, and now you will die.
Semi-automatic weapon fire, Arakssor cries out.
Let him go, Arakssor.
Lord Barset.
I don’t know what your plan is, Doctor, but you’d better get on with it.
Thank you, your Lordship. Just one final boost.
Loud signal.
Stay where you are, Arakssor, or I fire at point-blank range.
It’s getting cold again, Lord Barset, so watch him, he’s getting stronger.
Sonic weapon, Barset cries out. Gunshots and thud.
(weak) Doctor. Doctor, stop him.
Sonic weapon, Barset dies.
You owed that man your revival!
He was a fool, and so are you, Doctor. I grow tired of your continuing existence.
[OC]: Red 0089 responding to Blue distress code 442. Code Arakssor. Respond.
Listen to me, Red zero whoever you are, Arakssor has escaped.
Silence!
Too late.
[OC]: Your identity is confirmed, Arakssor. The distress call is verified. Where is Geldar?

He is dead. Executed as all traitors should be. Which side are you on, Commander? The side of our people’s true destiny of power, of glory, or are you of the cringing creed who failed to imprison me? Come, join me.
[OC]: Your sentence was life imprisonment. The penalty for escape is death. Sentence to be carried out immediately.
Boom!
Wait a minute! What are you doing? You’re bombarding us from space. Commander, listen to me.
[OC]: The affairs of this primitive planet do not concern us.
Commander!
